---
title: "Using grepcidr to find IP addresses in text files"
date: 2020-09-01T14:49:06-05:00
toc: false
images:
categories:
  - tech
tags: 
  - cidrgrep
  - network
---

For the longest time I used regular expressions or basic `grep` patterns to look for IP addresses within text files.  These methods make it very difficult to find specific IP addresses in a range if it does not fall on an easy to match pattern.  

Use `grepcidr` to eliminate RegEx and pattern matching.   This command will match any IP address in the typical CIDR boundary.  

Given a list of IP addresses:

```
192.168.37.1
192.168.37.2
192.168.37.6
192.168.37.7
192.168.37.10
192.168.37.14
192.168.37.16
192.168.37.17
192.168.37.18
192.168.37.20
192.168.37.22
192.168.37.23
192.168.37.28
192.168.37.30
192.168.37.32
192.168.37.34
192.168.37.36
192.168.37.42
192.168.37.43
192.168.37.48
192.168.37.50
192.168.37.51
192.168.37.52
192.168.37.55
192.168.37.59
192.168.37.61
192.168.37.64
192.168.37.68
192.168.37.72
192.168.37.74
192.168.37.75
192.168.37.77
192.168.37.84
192.168.37.85
192.168.37.88
192.168.37.89
192.168.37.94
192.168.37.95
192.168.37.96
192.168.37.97
192.168.37.98
192.168.37.99
192.168.37.103
192.168.37.106
192.168.37.110
192.168.37.111
192.168.37.114
192.168.37.118
192.168.37.120
192.168.37.121
192.168.37.135
192.168.37.136
192.168.37.137
192.168.37.140
192.168.37.141
192.168.37.157
192.168.37.158
192.168.37.162
192.168.37.165
192.168.37.169
192.168.37.171
192.168.37.174
192.168.37.177
192.168.37.179
192.168.37.180
192.168.37.183
192.168.37.184
192.168.37.185
192.168.37.186
192.168.37.187
```

Example searches:

```
jemurray@mbp-2019:~ $ grepcidr 192.168.37.0/30 demo-ips.txt
192.168.37.1
192.168.37.2
```

```
jemurray@mbp-2019:~ $ grepcidr 192.168.37.0/29 demo-ips.txt
192.168.37.1
192.168.37.2
192.168.37.6
192.168.37.7
```

```
jemurray@mbp-2019:~ $ grepcidr 192.168.37.128/28 demo-ips.txt
192.168.37.135
192.168.37.136
192.168.37.137
192.168.37.140
192.168.37.141
```
